data.title: The Giant Rocks @ Anse Source d'Argent, La Digue, Seychelles
data.meta_description: Nikon D850 Nikon AF-S NIKKOR 14-24MM F/2.8G ED Lee Soft GND 0.9 Lee Square Circular Polarizer This is the most amazing part of La Digue. Very often of not; you can actually get into the water to capture the images. As there is a big rib of swallow water around the island; it is easy to get into the water and make some cool and different perspectives. This was one such day. The tide was coming hard. That is important for this shot to show those rocks kind of rising up from the water. Otherwise with the lower water level shows too much of the rock not making it that interesting. From the image perspective; very basic 8 seconds exposure. Waited for the right time to get break at the cloud as well as to have some of the swimmers to go out of the frame. Asked my son to swim behind me and not in front of the camera for some time as he was enjoying jumping from those rocks into the water. But he does understand the importance of photography for me. So he was all right to give me the space needed. Overall a good memory of an amazing location. Ok. If you have already reached till here; may be you will be interested to see Seychelles in a bit more detail! Click here to see the short film documenting the natural beauty of the region as I have experienced it. Please have a look at my website www.avisekhphotography.com for all my recent works. Have a nice weekend. Hope you will enjoy the picture. Any suggestions or criticisms are always welcome.
data.text:
Nikon D850

Nikon AF-S NIKKOR 14-24MM F/2.8G ED

Lee Soft GND 0.9

Lee Square Circular Polarizer

This is the most amazing part of La Digue. Very often of not; you can actually get into the water to capture the images. As there is a big rib of swallow water around the island; it is easy to get into the water and make some cool and different perspectives.

This was one such day. The tide was coming hard. That is important for this shot to show those rocks kind of rising up from the water. Otherwise with the lower water level shows too much of the rock not making it that interesting.

From the image perspective; very basic 8 seconds exposure. Waited for the right time to get break at the cloud as well as to have some of the swimmers to go out of the frame. Asked my son to swim behind me and not in front of the camera for some time as he was enjoying jumping from those rocks into the water. But he does understand the importance of photography for me. So he was all right to give me the space needed. Overall a good memory of an amazing location.

Ok. If you have already reached till here; may be you will be interested to see Seychelles in a bit more detail!

Click here to see the short film documenting the natural beauty of the region as I have experienced it.

Please have a look at my website www.avisekhphotography.com for all my recent works.

Have a nice weekend.

Hope you will enjoy the picture.

Any suggestions or criticisms are always welcome.
